name: Mark Warner

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: I am remaining vigilant that election subversion remains possible ‚Äì either as certification continues or in elections down the line. While a lot of high-profile candidates lost, election deniers were elected (or reelected) up and down the ballot, and they will have power.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: I want to commend the brave actions of election workers across the country, who confronted the threat to our elections head on. It is thanks to their commitment to upholding democracy that we had such a smooth process.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: There are some worrying signs, however. A handful of counties resisted certification of the final vote. And angry crowds protested vote certification processes across the country. The certification of the statewide vote in Michigan, for example, was briefly disrupted.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: First of all, a lot of the news is good. Elections were largely peaceful, open, and fair. Many high-profile election deniers lost their races. Most certification processes across the nation appear, for the most part, to be going smoothly.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: I‚Äôll be monitoring harassment of election officials and voters, obstruction of valid results, bogus legal challenges, and the election of anti-democracy candidates. These midterms have the potential to be a staging ground for outright election subversion down the line.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: So with midterms approaching, I want to affirm my trust in the validity of our voting system and the reliability of the results. Get out and vote in these critically important elections. Democracy is literally on the ballot.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: This isn‚Äôt idle speculation ‚Äì it‚Äôs already under way. In primaries this cycle, three counties in PA and one county in NM refused to certify election results and had to be forced by state court action. I think it‚Äôs likely we‚Äôll see more legal tests of how far counties can go.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: With more election deniers in power in 2022, and hundreds more near-guaranteed to be elected in time for 2024, we could see a coordinated effort ‚Äì from grassroots county officials to senators ‚Äì refusing to certify valid results, casting doubt, or obstructing the transfer of power

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: I‚Äôm confident that honest officials will administer a fair contest. But these kind of tactics by election deniers could cause disruptions on Election Day, and even cause some counties to try to refuse to certify the vote.

name: Mark Warner

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: We also have another bill that will increase penalties for threatening election workers, help USPS handle election mail, and more. I‚Äôd like to have gone farther, but this represents a good start towards preventing future events like Jan. 6 and restoring trust in our elections.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: And it rests on our ability to ensure that entities that come into contact w/ that financial infrastructure comply w/ the governance regime we‚Äôve established. We must be clear that innovation/decentralization is not a license to evade the core governance regime the US maintains.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: Our nation‚Äôs geopolitical influence ‚Äì our ability to ensure compliance with AML rules, to combat illicit finance and terrorist financing, is predicated on our nation‚Äôs central role in global financial infrastructure.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: But we don‚Äôt want to create opportunities for bad actors to evade the sensible and important set of governance rules that we‚Äôve established to ensure that financial networks aren‚Äôt enabling illicit activity.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: As a former venture capitalist and someone who‚Äôs enthusiastic about innovation, I want to maintain America‚Äôs lead in financial innovation, including distributed ledger technologies.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: While that amendment did not pass due to objections, I look forward to continuing to work with my colleagues on this important issue.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: Following robust conversations, I‚Äôm pleased to have worked in good faith with my colleagues @SenToomey, @senrobportman , @SenLummis, and @SenatorSinema to reach a compromise amendment that would have memorialized and clarified all of this.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: Ultimately the exact wording describing those validating distributed ledger transactions doesn‚Äôt even matter because ‚Äì again ‚Äì the Administration & the drafters have made clear to all Senators that validators aren‚Äôt covered by the rules under any conceivable consensus mechanism.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: Our amendment *only* mentioned proof of work explicitly because that seemed to be the greatest alarm ‚Äì based on mischaracterizations and misinterpretations ‚Äì of the underlying text. @robportman and I revised our amendment to make clear that both miners and stakers aren't covered.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: Some have misinterpreted previous language I had offered to favor proof of work cryptocurrencies ‚Äì the intent was anything but: to reiterate, all the drafters have repeatedly emphasized they do *not* see validators under any consensus mechanism as subject to compliance.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: Thus, in good faith, I and others worked with Treasury to craft a compromise amendment that sought to dispel those concerns ‚Äì including making clear to folks expressing concern that miners would not be covered.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: While the Admin had been clear that they would not seek to collect or require information from any entities who could not collect or possess it, we realized that there was clearly a lot of confusion and consternation out there.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text:
As @FACTcoalition has emphasized, that clarification from my colleagues was not necessary ‚Äì and would have hastily and over-broadly carved out DeFi exchanges and custodians, even when they *are* in a position to collect this compliance information.
https://t.co/9KlxYSAVVm

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: My colleagues' amendment to the underlying bill would ‚Äì in the eyes of @FACTcoalition ‚Äì actually take a step *backwards* in key respects, including (in @FACTcoalition's eyes) undermining the bipartisan AML law Congress enacted law year. https://t.co/MmjLZCMFGb

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: To be fair, obscure provisions of tax law aren‚Äôt something most Americans have a passing familiarity with. And in an area as complex and fast-moving as digital assets ‚Äì it benefits all of us to be clear and get things right.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: They‚Äôve made clear the scope of these provisions is limited ‚Äì and said repeatedly to Senators that it would not capture miners in proof of work contexts, nor validators in proof of stake contexts. Nor would it capture devs simply contributing code to cryptocurrency projects. https://t.co/lpqg1BKrGA

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: For over a week, the Administration has reiterated to all Senators involved that the scope of these rules would not extend to parts of the crypto ecosystem where entities wouldn‚Äôt in their normal course of business be able to collect the relevant information for tax reporting.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: A bipartisan group of Senators rose to this challenge ‚Äì clarifying Treasury authority (and ratifying Treasury proposals that have been public since this spring) ‚Äì in the context of a vitally important and long overdue infrastructure package.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: Second, it‚Äôs well-understood that if you pay for something in more than $10,000 cash, there‚Äôs a reporting requirement. The bill made clear that this applies to crypto, too, as Treasury had proposed. Even @BlockchainAssn claimed this was common sense https://t.co/U5R8qocw4C

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text:

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: In this second part of the series, I argue that the U.S. must start investing in American workers.¬†If we are to create an inclusive 21st century economy, we must reform misaligned incentives to boost and ensure public and private investments in workers.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: America‚Äôs past economic success was closely tied to our ability to prepare workers for success over their lives and through multiple sectors. Unfortunately, over the past several decades, we have seen a shift in business norms that threatens to leave workers behind.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text:
The proposals surround 7 pillars: 
 
1. Boosting Investment in Workers
2. Facilitating Lifelong Learning
3. Investing in Community Colleges
4. Promoting Skilled Workers
5. Funding R&D
6. Improving Human Capital Disclosure
7. Reforming the TAA Program

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text:
CEOs repeat the adage, "our best asset is our people." To put this into practice in the 21st century, we must realign our incentives to encourage inclusive economic growth.
 
Here's the 2nd part of my 3-part series on the future of American capitalism:
https://t.co/CtbzfgMRfE

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: In this first part of the series, I argue that we need to create a robust and portable safety net for all Americans, regardless of the type of work they do, how much they make, or how long they have been at a job.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: But, American capitalism no longer holds the promise it once did. If nothing changes following the end of the COVID-19 pandemic and opportunities continue to concentrate for the most privileged, the promise of a robust middle-class life will be out of reach for many Americans.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: We used to get this right. In the 20th century following World War II, America‚Äôs entrepreneurial free enterprise system lifted millions of families out of poverty, creating the world‚Äôs strongest middle class.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text: Today, we see corporation after corporation outsourcing low wage workers ‚Äì usually without any benefits. In a pandemic, that makes our entire society vulnerable. We need to create a 21st-century social contract.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text:
The proposals are organized around 3 central pillars of reforms: 
 
1. Rebuilding the safety net for a 21st century economy. 
2. Reorient priorities to invest more in workers. 
3. Reform our corporate system for a more sustainable form of capitalism.

name: Mark Warner
tweet_text:
COVID has taken a toll on our society. We‚Äôre seeing a rise in permanent job loss, and it‚Äôs likely to worsen. For a more resilient economy in the 21st century, we need to shift modern American capitalism's focus. 

Here's the first part of a 3 part series:
